Replies.Reply: So what do you figure?
No idea at all?
Like when?
For sure?
Hi Gummy.
I know.
They bust you every week.
start paying rent.
I don't know how he doesn't know. He doesn't know.
Why not?
Are you on a scavenger hunt of some kind?
I always liked this part of town.
What a coincidence.
Then I found out Hopalong Cassidy had shot himself in the game room. That just blew it for me.
Hopalong Cassidy. Killed himself here.
I don't work for you yet, assface.
I commend you on your Spanish.
Ahh, the library. Masculine but sensitive.
Really, I love what you've done with the place.
I'm all ears.
---Finally regains the gift of speech.
You don't look sick, Mr. Stanwyk.
Why don't you try suicide?
So why pick me?
Maybe I'm just on vacation.
Did it ever occur to you that I might not want to kill you?
I'm still here.
Wouldn't they normally be locked?
I have the same problem with my help.
I rent them. Monthly lease, with an option to buy.
So it looks like a burglary attempt. You catch me. I get the gun, and shoot you.
What's the difference? The noise'll kill you first.
I don't think you'll have to worry about that.
Sure, all drifters do.
Take it where?
Where am I going?
They serve dinner on the flight?
You've certainly thought this out, haven't you?
You sure those doors will be open?
The gun, the money, the tickets, and the dying.
You sure got the hard part.
Sure.
Hey, Larry!
Can I steal you for a minute?
Deal.
Kareem's in the wash. I need a favor.
Don't say shoot, okay.
Did you hear something?
Me neither. See what we've got on a guy named Alan Stanwyk, okay? I need it right away.
W-Y-K no 'c.' I'll be down in a minute.
Frank, you look a little peaked. Wanna vomit?
Uh, almost.
And a damn fine one, I might add.
Oh, I hate it when he calls me that.
I will, Frank, I will. Something came up, okay?
I never read the paper.
What's the spread on the game tonight?
Looks great.
'Shame of Our City' is so good.
Walker just stares at him.
Just kidding, Frank. You'll have the story and you'll be damn proud of it.
Practically.
He's not the story! There's a source behind him.
Well, there we're in a gray area.
I'd say charcoal.
Frank, you animal, I love it. I'll have the story by Thursday night, I swear to God.
I hope.
Spot right here.
Thanks.
Maybe.
I wonder if that's his doctor.
We play tennis at the club.
Yes.
Well, I haven't played in a while because of these kidney pains.
That's Babar.
One. B-a-b-a-r.
But not right next to each other. I thought that's what you meant.
I don't know. I don't have any.
No books. No elephants either. No really good elephant books.
Still, it'd an odd name. I don't remember seeing it on the club registry.
Oh, I don't belong formally. I've gone with my aunt.
Mrs. Smith.
Right.
Margaret.
It was. Really a shame. To go so suddenly.
Sure, but the end was so sudden.
Yes, but the very end, when he actually died, that was extremely sudden.
You know, Alan and I were recently speaking of dying. Told me Boyd Aviation took out a lot of insurance on him. You must have to be in some kind of perfect health to get that kind of policy.
Honest, I feel fine. You better be married.
Did I say 'kidneys'? I meant my ear. Maybe I should see an ear dahhh --
Ever serve time?
Replies.Didascalie: (as Dolan starts to probe from behind)

Replies.Reply: Anyway, I'm surprised Alan got the policy so easily.
Whoa, look out there. You really need the whole fist?
Gee, Alan's been looking kind of sick lately.
I'm sure it's not for a lack of looking. Maybe I should get a real complete physical. You give Alan an annual, don't you?
I hope they still fit. Do I get to keep the glove?
Thanks, Doc. Maybe I'll come back with a date.
It's me doctor Rosenpenis. I just have to take another peek at Alan Stanwyk's file. What have they done with this place?
Right. Fine.
Not recently.
Uh, I'm not really prepared. My hands aren't sterilized.
Where am I?
I'm fine.
Have you got a make-shift plywood pillory? Heh Heh, just kidding.
Well, I didn't want to say anything, but I thought the dead man was my brother.
It's all right. It wasn't him but that spleen was a splitting image.
Oh, God, I think I'm about to hyperventilate.
Thank you.
My associates did a biopsy on this man recently.
He's supposed to have a melanoma, or a carcinoma, some kind of noma. Hmmm. I can't seem to find any record of it.
That's it?
This was last month. So Alan Stanwyk does not have cancer.
He'll be so relieved.
Christ.
What about breaking and entering?
Are you wearing anything under that?
I hate to conduct business on the lanai. Why don't we step inside.
One on one?
And the foul.
She doesn't need the money, for crissakes. She's living with Monty. I know it.
It stinks. I thought woman were independent now.
Hey, shut up, okay? I just hate this.
My lawyer was a bum.
I think he was sleeping with Wendy, too.
Are you serious?
Wait a minute! Our problems might be solved.
I think I just won a million dollars!
Found it in a cab. That's a grand.
Thank God.
Gail Stanwyk!
I haven't seen you since the wedding, Jeez, you look great.
I do? Oh, isn't that sweet, thank you. I have to confess something to you. I must have been pretty plowed at your wedding.
Huh? No, not my wedding. Yours.
John! You used to fly together!
John Ultrarelamensky.
Oh, I'm sorry. It's a beautiful name, really.
It's Scotch-Rumanian.
That's a strange combination.
So were my parents.
Please.
Yes, I'm with the Underhills.
They'll be back. He had to go in for a urinalysis.
Great. I'll have a Bloody Mary and a steak sandwich.
You should play with much larger tennis balls. So how's Alan?
Preoccupied with what?
Good. Lobs are a very important part of the game.
Why do you keep doing this?
Try stepping into the ball with your left foot.
There, much better.
I have this effect on lots of women.
Say, the reason I asked about Alan is that I bumped into him this morning and you know what I can't figure out?
I can't figure out why I went to Utah for the morning.
I'm such a heel. How'd you guess?
You are a rich woman.
What's he doing in Utah?
I thought I was going to die.
Thank you.
Okay.

First of all, let me just reiterate that this is not a formal investigation. I'm not going through formal channels here, because if Alan Stanwyk is not involved in any improprieties, then nobody has to know I was even ---
Look. You know that and I know that, but somebody's bucking for a promotion. I think it's that bozo, Hanrahan, I can't be sure.
I feel like dirt. They even want to know what he's doing in Utah?
God I admire you.
Comanche Indian.
Oh, Margie, sorry, Frieda lost the number of Alan's realtor in Provo. Can you give it to me real quick?
Yeah.
Frieda's boss.
My secretary.

See if you've got anything in Stanwyk's background from when he lived in Utah. Also check on a realtor in Provo named Swarthout. And tell Frank I'm crazy about him and I'd like to discuss his maybe moving in with me.
Later.
They're after Gummy again. It's weird.
Hey, what are you doing?
You don't have to run with me, Crease.
Why are you beating up on that kid?
He's defenseless, and you kick the crap out of him.
What goddamn right do you have to take him?
They didn't do anything.
I busted their window, they didn't do anything.
Not luck. They don't want me.
Cool your tool, Frank, I need a little more time. I think I'm really on to something here.
I really don't want to spoil your surprise, Frank.
She needs me, Frank.
That's okay, Lar. I gotta put this on the back burner for a while.
All right. Maybe there are some crooked cops involved in all this.
Yeah.
More cops.
I think I gotta go to Utah, Frank.
Yeah. It's wedged in between Wyoming and Nevada.
I have some ideas.
Very possibly. Come on, say yes. I'll buy you a shirt.
Nothing to it.

wearing a polyester brown suit -- fiddles with the radio. Snatches of programs are heard: "easy listening" music; country-and-western; a revival show; a call in show -- "Hi, you're on the air." "Hello, Bob, I'd like to discuss the death penalty. As you know, Jesus was in favor of it --" Fletch whistles and switches the radio off. He turns the car off the interstate.
Hi, Jim Swarthout, please. Oh, hello, my name is Igor Stravinski and I'm looking for some ranch property.
No, I just heard some people at the club talking about the property you sold him, and the way it was described, three million sounded like a pretty good price.
What?
Are you sure?
Of course. I guess I was misinformed. Listen, I'd love to come out and see you anyway.
Tomorrow.
What's your name fella? Fluff? Pom-pom?
He pockets the broken credit card, steps back and looks over the house for another possible point of entry.
Sit-tuh!
Roll over. Play dead. Good boy.
You any relation to Doctor Dolan?
I hate this.
Make sure nobody comes in, okay?
So much for your three million dollar ranch.
Suck on this Cujo!
Look! Defenseless babies!
If I took that out, you guys couldn't fit in here.
You just planted that.
Read me my rights.
Hold it! I'll waive my rights.
I hear he's mellowed a lot since he came out of the closet.
You decorate this yourself or did Mrs. Chief of Police help you?
Fletch.
I'm President of the International Fletch Corporation.
Frankly sir, you look a little like my father. Probaly explains the curious feeling of love I have for you.
It was planted on me, sir.
'Your men' might just be involved in all this.
Hey, you and Tommy Lasorda. That's great.
I don't like Tommy Lasorda.
You can't keep me here.
I'm no lawyer, but I do believe that's a violation of my rights.
My God, you're serious.
Can I ask anybody now?
Can I call my Mom? I'd like to tell here how much I've always loved her.
I hate the beach. Wouldn't go there if you paid me.
Not a prayer.
How could you call him?
It's also called getting me this close to being murdered.
He threw me in a cell, took a gun and a knife and threatened to kill me right there if I didn't promise to give up the story.
You'll have it.
Thanks for the vote of confidence, Frank.
Print this Frank.
Hi, where's Mrs. Stanwyk?
Oh, that's right. She told me to meet her there.
One.
I would, actually.
Right. Tell you what -- have you caviar?
I'd better only get two. How about the lobster thermidor?
Fine. And a couple of bottles of Dom Perignon. To cabana one.
This is just the nicest place.
Znhcneelsky.
Hi.
Hi.
I was hoping you'd say that.
Can I borrow your towel for a minute?
I ordered lunch.
Well, I knew this is where my mouth would be.
No, I think you should stay the same wonderful person you are today.
Here, take mine.
Yes.
Come on in.
No thanks, I'll do it. Give yourself twenty dollars. Underhill.
Sierra del fuego.
I saved his life during the war.
No. He was. I got him out.
'I've been so many places in my life and times.
'But we're alone now, and I'm singing this song for you.'  MRS. STANWYK Just like Alan. It's freaky.
Can I ask you a question?
Are you still in love with Alan?
Why'd you let me in?
Thanks, I feel much better. Listen, if you're so bored, why didn't you go to Utah with Alan?
Good point.
What about his parents?
How come?
Thanks for the great time.
What is this?
Long story.
Apparently, someone of your acquaintance has charged the most extraordinary lunch to my bill.
John!
Take one end.
I'll be leaving now, Mrs. Stanwyk.
Gail. I hope this won't embarrass you in any way. I think Underhill's a yutz, you won't have any trouble with him.
Yeah.
Yeah. My name's not John Ultramalensky and I wasn't at your wedding.
Irwin Fletcher. I write a newspaper column under the name Jane Doe.
So, your husband hired me to kill him.
That's what I want to know.
He told me he was dying of cancer.
He's a bad guy, Mrs. Stanwyk. Gail.
Have you ever heard the name Jim Swarthout?
MRS. STANWYK But I've seen the deed.
You saw a forgery.
That's the real deed.
Now, if this were at all legible, you'd believe me.
Here's this dog that tried to eat me.
I don't know. All I know is that he told me a lot of things and so far not one of them has been true.
I'm really sorry I have to tell you all this.
Mrs. Stanwyk?
Just wait, all right?!?
I'm going to call my father. He'll know what ---
No. You can't. Look, I know you don't know me from Adam, but you've got to trust me.
Just give me twenty-four hours. Please. Someone almost killed me today. People are not being nice lately, and I don't want you getting hurt. I think you're terrific. Are you a Laker fan?
I'll take you to a game.
I'm talking about how much I'd like to take you to a Laker game.
Act natural.
If you need me, call the paper. Hand me that extra bottle okay?
Jesus.
Should've known. Goddamn it.
Great. First I'll get a speeding ticket, then they'll shoot me. Terrific.
All right, fella, smog check. Move over.
Sorry, youngster, but we have to see what kind of fluorocarbons this thing puts out at ninety-five.
Don't worry about the speed limit. That's what the police escort's for.
Okay, kid. Just stand here with your hands on the car and wait for the cops. I gotta pee.
Hello. I'm with the hotel catering. Are you enjoying your meal? Carrots overcooked?

Many of you are probably not aware of Freddie's lifelong commitment to honoring a profession that frequently goes unsung -- the police. Many times Fred used to forsake a night with his wife and children to go out an sell tickets for the Policemen's Benevolent Association.
Our men in blue are with us today, and I think we should all extend a shake of the hand, a slap on the back and a 'howdy' to them.
When was the last time you hugged a cop?
Let them know how we feel, with a song. For every cop on every beat in every city of this great nation.
Everybody!
You're kidding.
Never heard of him. Thanks anyway.
What?
Oh, thanks.
The door was unlocked.
No wonder.
I commend him on his choice.
I commend him on his choice  The Man stares at him, holding the gun. He's not the brightest guy in the world, and Fletch has already caught on to that.
I was supposed to meet Mrs. Cavanaugh.
Don Corleone. I'm a cousin of Mrs. Cavanaugh's.
Where is she?
She moved out?
I spoke to her last week. She didn't say anything.
So you're saying she moved out.
This morning? Christ. We had so much to talk about.
Mattress police. There are no tags on the mattress.
I'm her cousin.
Go ahead. Call them. Better tie your shoelaces first.
I'm getting real tired of all this hostility.
Evening.
They oughta recall these things. One bump,the whole window goes.
Are you Mr. Marvin Stanwyk?
I'm Harry S. Truman from Casewell Insurance Underwriters.
My parents were great fans of the former President.
Sure did. Dropped the big one on them.
Right.
I don't doubt it, Mr. Stanwyk. Actually, my company is the sub-insurer of the subsidiary carriers of a policy held by Alan Stanwyk, who I believe is your son.
California. San Berdoo. Utah's part of my route.
First, a couple of routine things: are you and you wife currently alive?
Velma. You and Velma are the parents of Alan Stanwyk, Beverly Hills, California, executive vice president of Boyd Aviation?
Okay.
Now, the last time you saw your son was when?
Ten days ago?
Isn't that nice. Since when?
Forgive me now for seeming personal, but we understand that there is a lady friend he sees here in Provo.
Trust me, sir. It's a comprehensive policy.
I'm sorry?
You've met her?
Has Alan ever mentioned the name Sally Ann Cavanaugh?
Has he?
Then he has.
Of course, his wife's name is Sally Ann Cavanaugh?
Do you happen to have a picture of Alan and his wife?
How long have they been married?
Mrs. Stanwyk, may I borrow this picture. I promise to send it back to you. It's routine, really. The actuarial people need to ---
No, thank you.
Frank told you that?
You kidding? I got an unbelievable story here, Lar.
Check every hotel in L.A. Start with the ones near the airport. Yeah. He's about to leave the country with her. Thanks, Lar.
'welluh bless my soul whatsuh wrong with me?
Question:  But as he pushed the button down, the tape pops out. He fumbles it back in, and then pushes another button.
What's wrong with my life?

Question: Why does a man marry a millionaire's daughter in Beverly Hills if he is already married to a girl who lives in a crappy one bedroom apartment in Utah? Answer: Three million dollars. Big Question: What's with Stanwyk and Cummings? I don't know. Bigger Question: Why does Stanwyk want me to kill him?
Miss, I believe this has already been eaten.
What's wrong, Gail?
No.
I think you better sit down.
Gail, please.
I got this from Alan's parents. By the way, they see him all the time.
I checked. There was no divorce.
I'm telling you he's not your husband at all.
And they're leaving the country tomorrow night.
Bastard.
I don't have all the pieces yet, but I'm close. I'll know tomorrow.
You cant do that.
They're trying to kill me!
You're going to have to trust me, Gail.
Come here.
Gum?
I'm the Sufi.
Don't call me Fletch. Don't look at me.
Cops are here. I can smell them.
Because I'm a newspaper reporter and I'm nailing Chief Cummings as the source for drugs on the beach. You're in big trouble, Gummy.
Sit back down.
Fat Sam is turning state's evidence.
He wrote me a nice deposition. He says he just received the drugs. You did the selling.
Sure you did.
Twenty years.
Where does the Chief get the drugs?
Rio de Janeiro, maybe?
That's Brazil.
Wait here for me, Gummy.
It's the only way you'll be safe. Believe me.
You don't know me.
I'm serious, Sam.
Affirmative.
Affirmative.
For me. I'm a reporter, Sam. I'm breaking the drug story and I got the chief red-handed. Gummy game me a deposition.
I'm gonna nail the chief. And you can help or ---
You don't have a piece of the action?
Wait five minutes, and go to my office.
What?
Gum thought Brazil.
I'm quitting, Frank. As of midnight tonight.
This is Fat Sam, and this is Gummy.
Their statements, naming Chief Cummings as the numero uno drug pusher from here to Oxnard. I want them to have federal protection under the paper's sponsorship.
I'm out, Frank. You lost faith in me.
Forget it.
I'm going to write the story. Just hold the last couple of paragraphs till ten o'clock tonight.
Make yourselves comfortable, guys, but don't leave the office.
You were going to can me, right?
Not really?
I'm sick of this place. I'm going to try out for the Lakers. They need a power forward.
I like your outfit. You got the fifty grand and the plane ticket?
Because I trust you, Alan. By the way, the name's Fletcher. I.M. Fletcher. I write a newspaper column under the name Jane Doe.
Read this, please.
Cut the crap and read it.
Unless my people hear differently, this letter goes out at midnight.
Pretty hefty. Keep reading.
You shouldn't be here.
He doesn't read my stuff well.

'Sally Ann and Alan were married four years ago and never divorced, making Stanwyk a bigamist even in Utah. Stanwyk is also traveling with three million dollars in cash, the result of Gail Stanwyk's conversion of Boyd Aviation stock.
That was stupid, Alan.
Ahem.
'Sally Ann can confirm all this when the police pick her up at the Airport Marriott.'  Mr. Stanwyk blanches. Fletch continues.
'By the way, Alan is a very big drug smuggler, but you can read all about that in tomorrow's paper.
The thing that really tipped it off for me was something your wife said to me while we were in bed together.
How similar in build you and I are.
Whoops.

'Whoops?' What do you mean 'whoops?' Don't say 'whoops.'  MR. STANWYK I mean, by the time your story gets published, I'll be on the beach. I understand extradition from Rio is very complicated. I'll bet for two murders it's even more so.
That is a lighter, isn't it?
Thank God, the police.
Don't ever call me 'Irwin,' okay?
I've got it all under control, Jerry. You can go now.
Whoa. Well, you two obviously have a lot to talk over, so we'll go catch the last ten minutes of Dynasty.
Go ahead. Make my evening.
I'm calling the police. Then I'm leaving. You wait here for them.
Away. I think it might take you a while to get your life back together. You don't need me around.
Don't go back in there.
You sure did.
Far out.
Larry? It's Fletch.
Oh, tell Frank I need a couple of months.
I gotta go, Lar.
Right.
What are you doing here?
No problem.
No idea.
Okay. Some idea.
Like tonight.
Jesus.
My pleasure.
What, the heat here?
The two surfer boys?
Thought so. What for?
You gonna nail the chief?
Oh, I'll help, Fletch. I'm a slave to that sonofabitch. He busted me, third offense, gave me a choice: Work for him or do fifteen long. All I get out of this is free snort.
Noooo. Free snort. That's it.
Gonna need it. That boy is dangerous. Fletch?
You find the source?
Rio. Know how he gets it in the country?
He's some reporter, this guy.
Hi Sam. Hi Fletch.
cops did it.
They busted me last week.
I know. I got bad luck or something.
Fletch?
What?
Why are they after you?
What's that?
I didn't sell nothing! I didn't sell nothing!
Fletch, I never sold nothing.
I dunno. Somewhere in South America, I forget.
Maybe, Fletch. Is that Brazil?
Yeah. Maybe.
Whaddyamean 'maybe'?
Fletch! Take off!
What are you doing?
Fletch, slow down.
Fletch, this is dumb.
Fletch!
Fletch!!!
Hey you're really nuts.
What? What are you talking about?
You're lucky.
Excuse me. I have something I'd like to discuss with you.
Get up.
Lock's busted.
I work for the landlord. He told me to watch out for the place.
What?
Who are you?
Moved out.
She moved out.
This morning.
What did you want under the bed?
I'm calling the cops. This is for the cops.
Tell the cops.
We can't talk about it here.
I'll give you a thousand dollars cash just to come to my house and listen to the proposition.
What?
Who?
What are you, doped up or something?
Come inside.
Buenas dias.
Here's my proposition, Mr. Fletcher.
I want you to murder me.
Here. On Thursday. I'd like you to shoot me dead.
The reason I ask you to do me this service is that I am facing a long, painful, and most certain death. You see, I have bone cancer.
It doesn't get any worse than that. Just eats you up, bit by bit.
My company has taken out a very large insurance policy on me. And I have a wife. Suicide would nullify my insurance. Murder does not.
You're a drifter, a -- pardon the expression --
Not with the scum you hang out with. I've watched.
I've got fifty thousand dollars says you will.
Fifty thousand and a guarantee you won't get caught.
I want it done Thursday evening, around eight PM.
Replies.Didascalie: (turns and goes to the French doors)

Replies.Reply: Sometimes yes, sometimes no. The staff usually forgets.
I will be here in the room, waiting for you.
Very good. My .357. Use it and no one can trace it to you. The room will be in some disarray.
Precisely. Are you a good shot?
Get me on the first shot, if you can.
Do you have a passport?
Fine. After you kill me, take the Jaguar.
LAX. Go to the Pan Am desk. There will be a ticket waiting for you.
Rio. Flight 306. Departs at eleven PM.
It'll be a first class-ticket. I'm sure you'll enjoy the ride. I would recommend staying down there at least a year, Mr. Fletcher.
I am not someone who leaves a great deal to chance, Mr. Fletcher.
Yes. All you provide are the gloves, the passport, and the aim. I'll take care of everything else.
That's right.
What do you say, Mr. Fletcher? You'll be doing me and my family a great service.
Will you kill me?
Buenas dias.
Fletch pushes through the double glass doors, still dresses in a beach mufti -- the jeans and Magic Johnson shirt, Puma sneakers.
Fletch starts climbing up the fire escape of his building.
Fletch is greeted ad-lib by several people as he walks through the cavernous newspaper City Room.
John Boyd, Gail Stanwyk's father. At seventy, he is probably Chairman Emeritus now; no longer running the day-to-day operations of the company, and thus somewhat grateful from the company.
Fletch breezes in, right up to the Secretary, whose nameplate reads MADELINE TURNER.
Whoa, check out the beach boy!
Looking very good, Fletch.
Yo!
Only if you promise not to return me.
'Magic' today, huh?
Shoot.
Not me.
No problem, boss.
Everything's recent.
Married Boyd Aviation. He's no dummy, that's serious coin.
Not our kind of people, you understand.
You doing a story on this guy?
Only one way to find out.
I need Fletch for a second.
Nothing on Gail Stanwyk, nothing on Jim Swarthout.
Did you say cops?
That's one thing I did find. It's from Last month, so it was in the unsorted pile.
My hero.
I overheard it. He thinks you're completely out of control, he said he was gonna can you as soon as he got the story. If I were you, I'd just chuck it, Fletch.
Sally Ann Cavanaugh.
Fletch. Fletch!
Fletch, I take it by your presence here that the story is done. Tell me I'm right.
Fletch.
No, I want an answer, Is the story done?
'Uh, almost' is not an answer. 'Yes Frank, it's all done': that's an answer.
Irwin, professional journalism time, now. Go back to the goddamn beach and finish the goddamn story!
No it's not okay. You have to have this in by tomorrow.
I don't know.
Look!
Now, Irwin, try to follow me. You can't run the ad and then not run the story.
You broke it? You know the source?
What's 'practically'? Is it Fat Sam?
So let's go! We run the pictures.
Who?
How gray?
I'm going to bite out your eyeballs, you know that?
Your onto something. That's good. What?
What do you want?
Speak, don't point!
Just give me a hint, all right?
What's that?
Utah?
What about finding the source?
Who? Donnie and Marie?
Go to transportation, get a ticket.
It's called journalism, Fletch. It's called getting both sides of the story. Something you apparently don't know anything about.
Get out of here.
homicidal police chiefs.
I want something I can print!
What?
Who the hell are they?
Jesus H. Christ.
Fletch, this is the greatest.
Fletch!
Fletch, you want an apology?
Not really.
I was upset.
Fletch.

A pile of mail is on his desk. On the walls are a team portrait of the Lakers, plus a couple of blow-ups of his column. Fletch writes under the name of Jane Doe. An unused word processor is on his desk, but the keyboard has been moved aside to make room for an old, much-used Royal typewriter.
A photograph of Stanwyk; a head shot. Hands turn the clipping paper. Next clipping: a social page spread on the wedding of Alan Stanwyk.

'Dear Sir: Alan Stanwyk murdered me tonight. The charred remains found by the police in the Jaguar are mine, not his. Mr. Stanwyk, using my name and passport, boarded Pan Am Flight 306 for Rio, where he intends to establish residence with ---'  He stares at Fletch.
Fletch, stripped to the waist. is being examined by Dr. Joseph Dolen, a rather imperious physician.
B. ROSENSTIEN, M.D.

Fletch abruptly empties his doctor's bag and puts on a long green gown, a cap and a face mask. He plugs the stethoscope in his ears, removes miscellaneous file folders filled with papers, closes the bag, and heads for Pathology.

Gail Stanwyk is on the other side of the net, loading tennis balls into the automatic serve machine. She is in her late twenties and quite attractive., but in a much more natural way than other women we see here. She is good natured and effervescent. Fletch steps up to the entrance of the court.

It's at the end of a long hall, and adjacent to the Autopsy Room and the Pathology Records Room. Over his shoulder we can see into the autopsy room where a gowned doctor is happily performing an autopsy.
Identification please.
Nothing. They're still there.
Are you all right, Doctor?
You're in the Records Room.
Can I get you something?
Doctor Holmes went to get you some smelling salts. He was quite surprised that you fainted.
Oh my God!
Yes, right away.
Here you are, Doctor.
Is there anything particular you're looking for?
Well, if he had one, it would certainly be in here.
Wait. Here it is. Yep. Surgical removal of two moles.
That's it.
I guess not.
Hey you!
Give me a hand for a second would you doctor?
Come on, come on.
Have you ever see a spleen this large?
Grab this, will you?
You're not going to make this guy any sicker.
You never really get used to the smell, do you?
Refusal to pay alimony is a jailable offense, Fletch.
I did not break nor enter. I simply chose an advisable location to await my client's delinquent husband.
You owe Wendy nine hundred and eighteen dollars.
I don't know what you're referring to. Wendy maintains her own residence.
Until she remarries, Fletch.
I empathize with your plight, Fletch. However, you threw her out.
You should have proved that in a court of law.
I agree.
You may be right.
That's history, Fletch. You owe us nine hundred and eighteen dollars.
This is no joke. If some kind of payment isn't made, we're going to have to contact the paper and garnish your wages.
Cash. I'm impressed.
Till then.
Fletch climbs in through the window, followed by Gillett. His small apartment is just barely furnished. A low basketball hoop is attached to the wall. Fletch takes a ball, offers it to Gillett.
How about Fletch?
Gosh, he makes it look so easy!
Excuse me sir. Are you a guest of the club?
They just left, sir.
Would you care for a drink while you're waiting?
Very good sir.
In her cabana, sir.
Cabana one.
Would you be caring for something to eat or drink, sir?
Charged to the Underhills, sir?
Yes, sir. Beluga. But it is eighty dollars the portion.
I recommend it.
Very good, sir.
You want I set up?
Muchas gracias.
Your guest, sir.
I believe he's with Mrs. Stanwyk.
Yes sir.
Your call is come through.
I love the outfits.
Stay!
I must be having an off day. I'm really a fabulous player.
I bet you do.
Alan's in Utah.
Okay. I'm delighted to have someone to talk to, and you're very cute, so I'm very flattered, but I'm also very married so you may as well forget --
If I had a nickel for every one of Alan's flyboy buddies who tried to pick me up, I'd be a rich woman.
See what I mean?
None of your business, now go away.
A sprawling, Hughes-like complex.
Sugar, Mr. Poon?
Alan Stanwyk is not involved in improprieties. Where the hell does the S.E.C. come off ---
Unbelievable.
Utah?

Jesus Christ! First of all, Alan Stanwyk does not own one share of stock.The three million dollars for the ranch in Provo comes from my daughter who converted some of her personal holdings, not company holdings. Now if anybody in DC wants to make something of that, bring 'em on. Until then, get the hell out of my face.
By the way: what kind of name is Poon?
Jim Swarthout?
And, I'm sorry, who are you again?
Who's Frieda?
have pulled up to the beach, lights flashing. The druggies are dispersing. Creasy is running towards Fletch.
Fletch's rented Fairmont speeds down the highway.
Fletch dials the phone in the small, sparsely furnished room.
his house talking on the phone, surrounded by pine-paneling, property tract maps and wall-mounted animal heads.
Good, Mr. Starinski, what'd you have in mind?
Uh huh. Oh are you a friend of Alan's?
Well, I'm about to close up shop and go out for the evening. How about first thing in the AM?
Great. See you tomorrow.

Fletch stops his car in front of the ranch-style house. A lighted sign in the yard indicate that this is indeed Swarthout Realty, but the house is dark; no one appears to be home. Somewhere in the yard a dog barks viciously, frantically.
Double-hung. Slightly warped, so that the upper half does not exactly true with the lower half.
Fletch tiptoes though the upstairs bedroom and down the stairs. From outside, he can still hear the dog snarling and barking.
As Fletch passes through the living room he sees the dog snarling at him through the living room window.
Fletch enters and looks around.
Fletch runs as fast as humanly possible towards his car, fishing for his keys as he goes. The dog -- having shaken off the people-food from his hateful face -- is seconds behind and closing.

Fletch parks his Olds halfway up on the sidewalk, and gets out. He climbs over the gates of the Stanwyk home, and drops down inside. He lands on the grass, trots around the shrubbery, heads toward the garage, and checks his watch.
Fletch parks his car halfway up on the curb, steps out carrying a small overnight bag.
Fletch comes down the hall signing "Billie Jean" is an excruciating falsetto.
Fletch is lead into the precinct house.
The Sergeant at the desk checks Fletch out.
Who we booking here, gentlemen?
Oh Yeah?
You'll like the Chief. Nice man.
I find he gets real mellow after he hits somebody a lot.
Easy fellas.
Be with you in just a second.
You should have seen what she wanted to do with the place. Mauve.
So what's your name?
Replies.Didascalie: (shakes his head and pushes his papers aside)

Replies.Reply: Full name.
I see. And what do you do for a living, Mr. Fletch?
Why are you doing this Mr. Fletch?
Your editor called me yesterday to respond to allegations you're about to print about police involvement in narcotics dealing.
I'm about to break that beach wide open, and I don't need some pennyante Woodward and Bernstein getting in the way of my men.
You idiot. Off the record, deep background: I've got that beach crawling with undercover cops.
If you keep nosing around, you make the bad guys just a little bit more cautious. That makes my job harder.
You go back to that goddamn beach, I swear to God I'll make you regret it.
Maybe I'm not going to keep you here.
Maybe I'm gonna blow your brains out.
Ask anybody.
What'll it be Fletch?
Its been very nice meeting you. I enjoy your column.
Speaking of which, you're not going to print anything before my investigation is through, are you?
That a boy.
Thanks for coming down to see us.
Greetings, everyone.
Put the gun down, Alan. I'll take care of them.
Under control? You idiot. You didn't know who he was?
Fat Sam left the beach today. So did Gummy.
What, 'long distance?' I couldn't help but hear you say something about Rio, Alan. You're not leaving with the eight hundred thousand dollars I staked you for the next load, are you?
the front page while you're basking in Rio.
This one's going to be even more fun.
Fletch is railing at Frank Walker.
It's is so fuzzy, shaky, and poorly framed that there's no way we can read the price on it.
Alan Stanwyk crosses the parking lot and gets into his Jaguar. He starts the engine, backs out of his reserved space, and pulls out of the lot.
Fletch is reading a copy of Sports Illustrated. He puts it down, starts his car, and pulls out of the lot.
Stanwyk's Jaguar tools down Santa Monica Boulevard. Fletch's car follows, several discreet car lengths behind.
We are getting into the increasingly rundown section of Santa Monica. The Jaguar turns off. Hold: Several beats later, Fletch turns off.

Because he's looking through the reflection of sunlight on the back window of the unmarked police car, Fletch's point of view is fuzzy, but we can just make out the form of someone else in animated conversation with Stanwyk.
Fletch pulls up to his house and stops the car.
Fletch peels off onto the Santa Monica Freeway.
Fletch cuts across two lanes of traffic and gets off the freeway. He loses the motorcycle cop who goes past the exit. The squad cars are thrown behind a bit, but still chase.
Fletch picks up a case of vegetables and walks through as if he belonged there.
40 YEARS OF SERVICE  Thirty tables of conservatively dressed, older men and women are enjoying lunch.
Two cops are in hot pursuit.
Yes sir, you are confirmed on Flight 306 to Rio tomorrow evening at 11 PM. First Class.
Would you like me to change anything?
We'd have no way of knowing that, sir.
Yes, there is. Cavanaugh.
You mean her.
Sally Ann Cavanaugh. Oh wait, she couldn't work in your office, she's not from around here.
She's from Utah.
as Fletch emerges from the Rent-A-Car office and drives off.
The shelves are bare.
Who the hell are you?
Fletch pulls up, gets out of the car and addresses the couple sitting on the porch of the house.
Harry S. Truman?
Isn't that nice. Good man. Showed the Japs a thing or two.
Dropped two big ones. Real fighter.
Well, I'm fully covered.
Yes. Where you from, Harry?
Come on in.
Velma.
Check.
Oh, about ten days ago.
That's right. Alan comes by every three weeks or so.
Since he moved to L.A.
What the hell does this have to do with insurance?
Well, you can forget about that lady friend business, Alan's the most loyal husband a girl could have. He dotes on that bride of his.
Well, of course we have. He brings her with him.
Boy, what the hell's the matter with you?
Course he has. That's his wife.
Of course they are.
Cute young thing, too.
His bride. Cute as a button.
Cute thing.
Oh, we've got lots of pictures. Let me show you some.
She's cute as a button.
Oh, that's all right, I've got lots more. Want to see the reception?
How about Marvin's sixty-fifth birthday party?
Fletch is on the phone.
Larry is on the phone.
Fletch is sitting in a semi-deserted flight on his way back home. He is hunched over an airline meal, eating with his right hand and turning in his mini recorder with his left.
Day three on the beach. Fat Sam still hasn't moved, and ---
A Sufi junkie.
is seated on a towel.
Fletch parades through the city room, still in his Sufi getup. He takes off the beard and heads for Frank Walker's office. Fat Sam and Gummy, looking like fish out of water, follow him.
The jaguar is parked just where it is supposed to be, and the key is in the ignition.
is in the library, sitting patiently at his desk.
Where are you going?
I really creamed the sonofabitch, didn't I?
John Ultramalensky, right?
God, I haven't seen you since the wedding.
Not mine, stupid. Yours.

I couldn't sit home and play the mournful widow anymore, and the police didn't need me, so I tried watching a Lakers game on TV, but the announcer talked to fast and I couldn't understand a lot of what was happening, so I figured if I came down here maybe you could explain the rules to me, and besides, I missed you.

With Sugarloaf Mountain in the b.g., Fletch lies in a lounge chair, sipping an exotic drink, watching the cavorting lovelies and playing his battered Casio. This is obviously at some very expensive beach club or hotel, as witnessed by the uniformed servant who brings a telephone.
